thread.title: Analysis: Nationals' Matt Williams was overmatched, inflexible in debut gig
thread.title_full: Analysis: Nationals' Matt Williams was overmatched, inflexible in debut gig

author: Joe Lemire, Special for USA TODAY Sports
title: Analysis: Nationals' Matt Williams was overmatched, inflexible in debut gig
text:
In his final weekend leading the most disappointing team in baseball, embattled Washington Nationals manager Matt Williams declined to campaign publicly to save his job, demurring when a reporter asked why he hadn’t responded to damning reports in the Washington Post (saying he had lost the clubhouse) and on CBSSports.com (indicating on Friday that the decision to fire him was already made). “I personally feel that it is my job to be a calming force as opposed to a disruptive one,” Williams said in Citi Field’s visiting manager’s office. “We have a lot of talented players on this team that I support wholeheartedly every single day. I will not stop doing that. Ever. Believe me when I tell you this: ever stop doing that. That being said, I’m not going to subject this team to any further distraction.”
While commendable to take the high road, his response could also have been interpreted as defeatist, his fate indeed having been sealed by bullpen and discipline mismanagements.
On Monday, the news was confirmed: the Nationals had fired Williams after two years, with the 2016 season guaranteed on his contract.
USA TODAY
Nationals fire manager Matt Williams
The 49-year-old, five-time All-Star third baseman with Giants, Diamondbacks and Indians had been named Washington’s manager prior to the 2014 season in which his club won 96 games and the National League East. Williams even received NL Manager of the Year honors but lost his job after the consensus most talented team — which added free-agent ace Max Scherzer to already potent rotation and roster — won just 83 games and finished seven games behind the Mets.
There are two major demands of a manager: the managing of people through communication, encouragement and discipline and the managing of the game through strategy. Williams appeared to fail at both.
In a conference call Monday, Nationals general manager Rizzo said Williams had “steadiness to him, a calm to him” and that “he led by example.”
The Washington Post cited players describing Williams as “tense” and that “he doesn’t talk to people in” the clubhouse, which was deemed a “terrible environment.” When closer Jonathan Papelbon choked star Bryce Harper in the dugout, Williams admitted he didn’t ask enough questions about what happened and allowed Papelbon to keep pitching. He even clumsily said he was benching Harper, even though he was the victim and already scheduled to get that next game off.
Similarly obvious were his tactical blunders. The discussion around Williams’ bullpen usage began in NLDS Game 4 last October when he didn’t use his best relievers — Tyler Clippard or Stephen Strasburg, who was available in the bullpen that day — in a pivotal seventh inning against the Giants’ best hitters, instead turning to rookie Aaron Barrett and demoted closer Rafael Soriano.
“Not one single incident was the tipping point of making the decision," Rizzo said Monday.
USA TODAY
Jonathan Papelbon attacks Bryce Harper in dugout fight
Furthermore, Williams was too rigid in when to deploy his best relievers, closer-turned-setup man Drew Storen and acquired closer Papelbon, often declining to use them in anything other than their prescribed roles of protecting leads in the 8th and 9th innings. Most glaringly, on Sept. 1, Williams used Casey Janssen in the ninth inning of a tied game even though Janssen had pitched poorly and taken the loss the night before and Papelbon remained available. Williams’ next-day explanation in a radio interview with 106.7 The Fan didn’t help matters, when he insisted of Papelbon, “He’s our closer,” as if he couldn’t pitch at any other time. Williams added a hypothetical: “Let’s say, for instance, Pap throws a clean ninth and we score in the 10th. Who’s closing the game for us? I guess it’d be ‘Somebody,’ right?” Again, there’s that rigidity.
Similarly, when facing the division rival Mets on July 31 and Aug. 1, Williams didn’t use either Storen or Papelbon in a pair of one-run losses. The Mets won the first game in 12 innings and the second when rallying for runs in the seventh and eighth innings — all high leverage situations.
Also, when Strasburg was visibly uncomfortable on the mound in an early May start, grimacing in the first inning without a visit from the trainer, manager or pitching coach. He ultimately was removed after three innings with an ailment.
Admittedly, Washington suffered an undue number of injuries this season — Strasburg didn’t miss a start then but was out a month later in the season; position players Ryan Zimmerman, Anthony Rendon, Jayson Werth and Denard Span all missed appreciable chunks of the season, as did starter Doug Fister.
Those disabled-list stints and a series of players under-performing when healthy couldn’t overcome Bryce Harper’s historic and likely MVP season. Williams alone probably couldn’t have turned this club into a contender, but it seems clear his continuing as manager would be detrimental to the Nationals moving forward.
Williams had served on Arizona manager Kirk Gibson’s staff for a few seasons before taking over in Washington, where he was thrust into the manager’s office of a club with high expectations — a difficult place for someone new to the role.
“Everybody learns every single day,” Williams said when asked to reflect on his growth. “You’re faced with challenges, whether it’s day one or the end of the second year — it doesn’t change as long as you manage. That being said, we work hard. We take this very seriously, and we want to win as many games as we can. I look forward to that on an every day basis, and that’s part of the grind. That’s part of the pleasure of the job, is to have those bumps and get over them. Learn. Be better.”
Williams did have one division crown in Washington, but a loaded Nationals expected far more than a distant second-place standing with negativity engulfing the franchise. Williams may well learn and be better down the road — it just won’t happen in Washington.
GALLERY: MANAGERIAL CAROUSEL
Oct. 5: The Nationals fire Matt Williams, who won the NL manager of the year award in 2014. He was in just his second season as a manager. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Aug. 14: Red Sox manager John Farrell takes a leave of absence after he was diagnosed with Stage 1 lymphoma. He will return for the 2016 season. Bob DeChiara, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen The Red Sox name bench coach Torey Lovullo as interim manager. Brad Penner, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen June 26: Ryne Sandberg resigns as manager of the Phillies. Eric Hartline, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen The Phillies name Pete Mackanin, the third-base coach, as interim manager. He is retained through the 2016 season. Robert Mayer,USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen June 15: The Padres fire Bud Black after nine seasons with the club. David Kohl, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen The Padres name Pat Murphy as the interim manager. He was let go after the season. Tommy Gilligan, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen May 17: The Marlins fire Mike Redmond after starting the season 16–22. Steve Mitchell, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen The Marlins GM Dan Jennings becomes manager. Steve Mitchell, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen May 3: The Brewers fire Ron Roenicke after starting the season 7–18 record, which was the worst record in baseball.
